name: Akeldama (Field of Blood)
shortDescription: The potter's field in Jerusalem purchased with Judas's blood money, named 'Field of Blood' because it was bought with the price of innocent blood
fullDescription: Akeldama (Aramaic: Haqel D'ma, 'Field of Blood') is a site in Jerusalem carrying dark significance in Christian tradition. According to the Gospel of Matthew (27:3-10), after Judas Iscariot betrayed Jesus for thirty pieces of silver and saw Jesus condemned, he was seized with remorse. He returned the blood money to the chief priests, declaring 'I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood.' When the priests refused to put the money into the temple treasury because it was 'the price of blood,' they used it to purchase a potter's field as a burial place for strangers. Matthew connects this to prophecy, quoting Zechariah 11:12-13 (attributed to Jeremiah). Acts 1:18-19 provides an alternate account: Judas himself purchased the field, and 'falling headlong, he burst asunder in the midst, and all his bowels gushed out,' hence the name 'field of blood' referring to his gruesome death rather than the blood money. The traditional site of Akeldama is located in the Hinnom Valley (Gehenna) south of the Old City, on the steep southern slope of the valley. The area was known for its clay deposits used by potters, explaining the designation 'potter's field.' By the Byzantine era, the site was used as a charnel house and burial ground. Today, a Greek Orthodox monastery (St. Onuphrius) marks the traditional location. Akeldama stands as a memorial to the consequences of betrayal, the corruption of blood money, and the fulfillment of prophetic scripture.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Akeldama represents the tragic end of betrayal - the blood money could not remain in sacred space, and the field purchased with it became a burial ground for strangers. The name 'Field of Blood' carries double meaning: bought with the price of innocent blood (Matthew) and marked by Judas's own blood (Acts). The site in Gehenna (Hinnom Valley) connects to Jewish associations of that valley with judgment and death.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Akeldama has been venerated since early Christianity as a site of moral instruction. The current Greek Orthodox monastery (St. Onuphrius) marks the traditional location. Medieval pilgrims noted the charnel house built to bury Crusader-era pilgrims. The site serves as permanent memorial to the consequences of valuing money over loyalty.

mythologyContexts.usage: Located in Hinnom Valley (Gehenna), area associated with death and judgment in Jewish tradition

textReferences.context: Jeremiah prophesies against the Valley of Hinnom, site of child sacrifice

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Hinnom Valley (Gehenna) was associated with child sacrifice to Molech and later became a metaphor for judgment. A potter's field in this location carried connotations of death and desolation.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The area's clay deposits made it suitable for potters, while its association with death made it appropriate for stranger burials.

matthiasConnection.significance: Akeldama is directly connected to Matthias's election. Peter's speech in the Upper Room (Acts 1:18-20) recounted Judas's fate at Akeldama as the reason why the apostolic twelve needed restoration. The vacancy created by Judas's betrayal and death - memorialized at Akeldama - led to Matthias being chosen by lot to fill his office.
matthiasConnection.keyPassage: Acts 1:18-20: 'Now this man purchased a field with the reward of iniquity; and falling headlong, he burst asunder in the midst, and all his bowels gushed out. And it was known unto all the dwellers at Jerusalem; insomuch as that field is called in their proper tongue, Aceldama, that is to say, The field of blood. For it is written in the book of Psalms, Let his habitation be desolate, and let no man dwell therein: and his bishoprick let another take.'
